sec_txt.h3: VTE in Cancer: What Do the Latest Data Suggest?
Risk of Cancer-Associated VTE[1-4]
sec_txt.li: Risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) is elevated in cancer
In general, patients with cancer have a 1:5 chance of developing VTE

VTE risk is variable and dependent on a number of factors, including
Cancer type (site of tumor)
Cancer stage
Time since diagnosis of cancer
Cancer treatment

sec_txt.h3: Risk Factors for Cancer-Associated VTE: Cancer Site[4]
sec_txt.li: The predominant risk factor is the location of the primary tumor
Overall, gastrointestinal (GI), pancreas, brain, lung, and ovarian cancer induce the highest risks
Relatively lower risks are seen in patients with breast or prostate cancer

sec_txt.h3: Risk Factors for Cancer-Associated VTE: Cancer Treatment Modality[5]
Risk Factors for Cancer-Associated VTE: Patient-Related Factors[5]
sec_txt.li:
Ethnicity
Risk greater with African American vs Caucasian vs Asian population
Attributed risk, however, is minor
Compression of major vessels by tumors

sec_txt.h3: Guideline Recommendations: Cancer-Associated VTE Treatment[6-8]
sec_txt.li: Most guidelines recommend monotherapy with low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) for at least 6 months
Latest data from VTE treatment trials with non-vitamin K antagonist oral anticoagulants (NOACs) are challenging the current treatment paradigm

sec_txt.h3: Challenges With LMWH
sec_txt.li:
LMWHs are injectable agents
Injectable agents are treated differently in prescription plans and copayment can be high
Daily self-injection adds to the burden of treatment

sec_txt.h3: Persistence With Anticoagulation for Cancer-Associated VTE[9]
sec_txt.li: Real-world analysis: LMWH was associated with significantly lower persistence and shorter duration of treatment

sec_txt.h3: VTE and Major Bleeding Risk in Patients Receiving Chemotherapy: A Real-World Analysis[10]
sec_txt.li: Patients with cancer are at high risk of both VTE and major bleeding
VTE and major bleeding can be fatal
Major bleeding can be difficult to treat; especially GI mucosal bleeding
Minor (eg, nuisance) bleeding is also common

sec_txt.h3: Treatment of Cancer-Associated VTE: Clinical Trials of NOACs[11-13]
Hokusai VTE-Cancer: Design[14]
sec_txt.li:
Study population with active cancer and symptomatic/incidental deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or proximal pulmonary embolism (PE)
DVT of proximal lower extremity (popliteal, femoral, or iliac vein thrombosis)
PE involving segmental or more proximal pulmonary arteries
All patients were treated for at least 6 months
Physicians were encouraged to continue treatment for 12 months

sec_txt.h3: Hokusai VTE-Cancer: Primary Outcome[11]
sec_txt.li: Edoxaban was noninferior to dalteparin

sec_txt.h3: Hokusai VTE-Cancer: Primary Outcome Components[11]
sec_txt.li: Rate of recurrent VTE was significantly lower with edoxaban vs dalteparin
Rate of major bleeding was significantly higher with edoxaban vs dalteparin
Most major bleeding occurred in patients with GI cancers

sec_txt.h3: SELECT-D: Design[15]
sec_txt.li: Study population similar to Hokusai VTE-Cancer

sec_txt.h3: SELECT-D: Primary Endpoint â€“ Recurrent VTE at 6 Months[12]
sec_txt.li: Rivaroxaban was associated with relatively low VTE recurrence compared with dalteparin

sec_txt.h3: SELECT-D: Major and CRNM Bleeding at 6 Months[12]
sec_txt.li: Rivaroxaban was associated with relatively higher clinically relevant nonmajor (CRNM) bleeding compared with dalteparin
Most of the major bleeding occurred in patients with GI cancers

sec_txt.h3: SELECT-D: Major Bleeding by Tumor Type[12]
sec_txt.li: Among GI cancers, most major bleeding was confined to upper GI cancers

sec_txt.h3: Hokusai VTE-Cancer: Major Bleeding by Tumor Type[16]
sec_txt.li: Excess major bleeding with edoxaban was confined to patients with GI cancer

sec_txt.h3: NOACs for Treatment of Cancer Associated VTE: Guidance From ISTH[17]
sec_txt.li: An estimated 60% to 70% of overall cancer population may be eligible for treatment with NOACs
In patients with high risk of bleeding, reassess therapy options when bleeding risk changes over time

Patients with severe thrombocytopenia are candidates for LMWH
LMWH can be dose-adjusted based on the platelet count
Fine tuning of dose is not currently possible with NOACs

sec_txt.h3: Anticoagulation in Cancer Patients With Thrombocytopenia: Guidance From ISTH[18]
sec_txt.li: Option to start with one therapy and switch to another when patient condition improves

For example, in patients with GI cancer
Could start therapy with LMWH
If bleeding risk improves, switch to a NOAC
If platelet count declines after switching to NOAC, bridge to LMWH until platelet count improves to safely resume NOAC

sec_txt.h3: Guidance for Prevention of Cancer-Associated VTE[19]
sec_txt.li: Clinical trials on thromboprophylaxis found benefit in patients with high risk score (Khorana score â‰¥3)
Although thromboprophylaxis is recommended in patients with cancer who are at high risk of VTE, it is not usually followed
